record_data.record_title: Baseline Operating Statement under 18 CFR Section 284.224
record_data.record_plain_text:
Operating Statement Under NGPA Section 311 Minnesota Energy Resources Corporation
Preliminary Statement
Minnesota Energy Resources Corporation (referred to in this Operating Statement as “Transporter”) engages in, among other things, the business of transporting natural gas for third parties. MERC has obtained a blanket certificate of limited jurisdiction under Section 7(c) of the Natural Gas Act in order to serve a Shipper located in Iowa. See Minnesota Energy Resources Corporation, 117 FERC ¶ 61,254 (2006). This Operating Statement is filed pursuant to Section 311(a)(2) of the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978 (“NGPA”), as amended, and the applicable Rules and Regulations of the Commission.
It is the policy of Transporter to provide transportation service pursuant to NGPA Section 311(a)(2) for an eligible Shipper only under written contract acceptable to Transporter and after consideration of Shipper’s creditworthiness; the Transporter’s existing firm transportation commitments to others; the Transporter’s firm retail and wholesale sales commitments to others; the system’s design capacity; the available system capacity; and other factors deemed pertinent by Transporter and applied on a non-discriminatory basis by Transporter.
This Operating Statement is filed to comply with 18 C.F.R. Section 284.123(e). This Operating Statement may be modified from time to time without advance notice to Shippers, and any such modification shall be binding on Shippers.
Statement of Rates
Rate for Transportation Service
1,500 therms or less per year Over 1,500 therms per year Section 311 Transportation $0.32387 per therm $0.25030 per therm Shipper charge per month $18.00 $45.00
1. DEFINITIONS
The following definitions shall apply hereunder:
a. British Thermal Unit. The term “British thermal unit” or “Btu” shall have the meaning ascribed to it by the Delivering Transporter.
b. Day. The term “Day” shall mean a period of time beginning at 9:00 a.m. Central Time on each calendar day and ending at 9:00 a.m. Central Time on the next succeeding calendar day.
c. Delivery Point(s). The term “Delivery Point(s)” shall have the meaning ascribed to it in Section 2.
d. Delivering Transporter. The term “Delivering Transporter(s)” shall mean the gas transmission Transporter acting in the capacity of a transporter, transporting gas for Shipper upstream of the Receipt Point(s).
e. Gas. The term “Gas” shall mean any mixture of hydrocarbons and noncombustible gases in a gaseous state consisting primarily of methane.
f. Interruptible. The term “Interruptible” shall mean that Transporter may interrupt service without liability due to the unavailability of capacity, operating conditions or system requirements.
g. Mcf. The term “Mcf” shall mean one thousand (1000) cubic feet of Gas measured at a base temperature of sixty degrees (60) Fahrenheit, and at a pressure base of fourteen and seventy-three hundredths (14.73) pounds per square inch absolute.
h. Month. The term “Month” shall mean a period of time beginning at 9:00 a.m. on the first day of a calendar month and ending at 9:00 a.m. on the first day of the next succeeding calendar month.
i. psig. The term “psig” shall mean pounds per square inch gauge.
j. psia. The term “psia” shall mean pounds per square inch absolute.
k. Receipt Point. The term “Receipt Point” shall mean the meter designated as Emmons TBS#1 on Northern Natural Gas Company.
l. Retail Gas Tariff. The term “Retail Gas Tariff” shall mean the Retail Gas Tariff approved by the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission, found at <http://www.minnesotaenergyresources.com/company/tariffs.aspx>
m. Volume. The term “volume” shall mean the amount of Gas transported by Transporter for Shipper and shall be computed at the standard unit of measurement.
2. RECEIPT AND DELIVERY OF GAS
Transporter agrees to receive, transport and deliver on an interruptible basis those Volumes of Shipper’s Gas tendered. The Delivery Point(s) shall be the meters identified as:
Address Meter Number 130 State Street Emmons, MN 20078837 190 State Street Emmons, MN 20079939 101 Main Street Emmons, MN 20112390
3. OWNERSHIP AND CONTROL
As between the Shipper and Transporter, Shipper shall be in control and in possession of the Gas delivered hereunder and responsible for any damages or injuries caused thereby until the same shall have been delivered to Transporter at the Receipt Points. After such delivery of Gas, Transporter shall be deemed to be in exclusive control and possession thereof and responsible for any injuries or damages caused thereby until the same shall have been redelivered for the account of Shipper at the Delivery Point(s).
4. PRESSURES
Delivery pressure of Gas by Transporter to Shipper for residential and general service will approximate four ounces. However, delivery pressure for such Shipper will normally not be less than two ounces or more than eight ounces as measured at the Shipper’s meter outlet. Delivery of Gas at a pressure of two psig will be provided to the Shipper upon request subject to Transporter approval and compliance with fuel line installation standards of Transporter and subject to distribution system design and capacity. Where the Shipper has entered into a standard Gas sales contract with the Transporter, deliveries of Gas will be made at the pressure specified in such contract. The Shipper shall install, operate and maintain at its own expense, such pressure regulating and relief devices as may be necessary to regulate the pressure of Gas after delivery to the Shipper.
5. QUALITY
Transporter agrees that all Gas delivered at the Delivery Point(s) hereunder shall be merchantable and shall meet the quality specifications of Transporter as specified in its Retail Gas Tariff.
6. METERING FACILITIES AND MEASUREMENT
The metering facilities to measure the volumes of Gas delivered at the Delivery Point(s) shall be maintained and operated or caused to be maintained and operated by Transporter. Shipper, at its cost, reserves the right to install check meters. Transporter shall determine the Btu content of the Gas at the Delivery Point(s). Facilities and measurement data with respect to the Gas covered hereby shall at all reasonable times be subject to joint inspection by Transporter and Shipper. The meters for measurement of volumes of Gas hereunder must be installed and operated and Gas measurement computations must be made in accordance with current industry standards.
7. METER TEST
Meter Standards 1. Meter: The Gas delivered by Transporter to the Shipper shall be measured by an adequate meter or standard type, installed, operated and maintained by Transporter. 2. Location: The town plant Shipper will provide a place on the Shipper’s premises at no cost to the Transporter for location of the meter. The location of a previously set meter may be changed by the Transporter at the request of the Shipper. The expense of the change shall be paid by the Shipper. (a) Domestic and Small Volume Commercial - Meters will be set and maintained on the Shipper’s premises at a location mutually acceptable to both the Transporter and the Shipper after giving due consideration to safety, accessibility for meter reading, prudent investment of materials and the prevailing practice in the community. Alternative locations must be approved by the Transporter. (b) Large Volume and/or Industrial - Meters will be set at Shipper’s property line nearest the gas main whenever possible. Alternative locations must be approved by Transporter. 3. Access: The Transporter’s authorized agents shall have access to the Transporter’s meters and pipes at all reasonable times for the purpose of inspection, maintenance, connect, disconnect, leak detection, meter turn off and to ascertain the quantity of Gas consumed or registered. 4. Testing: Transporter shall test its meters at reasonable intervals and shall at the time of the test adjust the meter to record accurately. 5. Shipper Requested Meter Test: Upon request, the Transporter shall make a test of the meter serving a Shipper provided that such tests need not be made more frequently than once in 18 months. If the meter is found accurate under the provisions of this Section 7, Subsection 6, the Transporter may charge the Shipper not to exceed thirty dollars (one hundred dollars for large volume equipment) or the actual cost of such test, whichever is less. The Transporter shall notify the Shipper in advance of the date and time of the requested test so the Shipper or a representative may be present when the meter is tested.
A report of the results of the test shall be made to the Shipper within a reasonable time after the completion of the test, and a record of the report, together with a complete record of each test shall be kept on file at the office of the Transporter.
6. Adjustment of Measurement Errors
(a) Fast Meters - Whenever any meter is found upon test to have an average error of more than two percent (2%) fast, Transporter shall refund to the Shipper the overcharge. If the error is due to a cause the date of which can be determined with reasonable certainty, then the refund will be computed from that date, but in no event for a period longer than one (1) year. If the period of the inaccuracy cannot be determined, then it shall be assumed that the full amount of the inaccuracy existed during the last half of the period since the meter was last tested but not to exceed six months.
If the recalculated bills indicate that a refund more than one dollar ($1.00) is due an existing Shipper, or two dollars ($2.00) is due a person no longer a Shipper of the Transporter, the full amount of the calculated difference between the amount paid and the recalculated amount shall be refunded to the Shipper. The refund to an existing Shipper may be in cash or as a credit on a bill. If a refund is due a person no longer a Shipper of the Transporter, a notice shall be mailed to the last known address and the Transporter shall, upon request made within three months thereafter, refund the amount due.
(b) Slow Meters - Whenever any meter is found upon test to have an average error of more than two percent (2%) slow, Transporter may charge for the Gas consumed during the period of inaccuracy, but not included in bills previously rendered. If the error is due to a cause the date of which can be determined with reasonable certainty, then Transporter may bill the Shipper for the amount that the test indicates has been undercharged for the period of inaccuracy, but not for a period longer than one (1) year. If the period of inaccuracy cannot be determined, then the charge shall be based on a corrected meter reading for a period equal to one-half of the time elapsed since the previous test, but not exceed six months. For the purpose of this billing adjustment, the meter error shall be one-half of the algebraic sum of the error at full-rated flow plus the error at check flow. No back-billing from the time of notification by the Shipper will be sanctioned if the Shipper has called to the Transporter’s attention his doubts as to the meter’s accuracy and the Transporter has failed, within a reasonable time, to check it.
If the recalculated bills indicate that the amount due Transporter exceeds ten dollars ($10.00), Transporter may bill the Shipper for the amount due. The first billing rendered shall be separated from the regular bill and the charges explained in detail.
(c) Non-Registering Meters - When the average error cannot be determined by test because the meter is not found to register or is found to register intermittently, Transporter may charge for an estimated amount of Gas used but in no event shall such charge be for a period longer than one (1) year.
7. Meter Reading
Meter readings of meters serving Shippers connected to Transporter distribution system shall normally be taken by the Transporter at intervals of approximately 30 days except where noted below. When access to a meter cannot be gained, the Shipper fails to supply a meter reading form in time for the billing operation or in case of emergency (storms, accidents, etc), billing based on an estimated reading may be rendered. Estimated bills shall be based on the Shipper’s historical actual consumption, if available, or rate schedule history where historical actual consumption is not available. In the case of a Shipper who has three consecutive estimated billings, the Transporter will use its best effort to obtain an actual reading. Each Shipper will receive at least one actual reading within a twelve month period. After a reading is obtained, if there is any material difference, an adjusted bill shall be rendered for the period since the last previous reading of the meter. The Transporter shall divide the municipality or territory into districts and will read meters in each district at a selected time.
No more than three estimated meter readings will occur for any Shipper, and no Shipper will receive estimated bills for two consecutive months more than one time per year.
8. ASSURANCE OF PAYMENT
The Transporter may require all customers to make a written application for service under this Operating Statement. If the application is approved for service it will be evaluated by the Transporter and a determination will be made of the need for a cash deposit sufficient to guarantee payment of bills for service rendered. A Shipper, who within the last 12 months has not had service disconnected for nonpayment of a bill and has not been liable for disconnect for nonpayment of a bill which is not in dispute, shall be deemed to have established good credit.
Deposits may be required if the existing Shipper has had service with the Transporter disconnected for nonpayment of an undisputed bill or has been issued a notice of disconnection for an undisputed bill within the last 12 months.
The Transporter may accept, in lieu of a deposit, a contract signed by a guarantor satisfactory to the Transporter, whereby payment of a specified sum not exceeding the deposit requirement is guaranteed. The term of such contract shall be for no longer than 12 months, but shall automatically terminate after the Shipper has closed and paid his or her account with the Transporter, or at the guarantor’s request upon 60 days’ written notice to the Transporter. Upon termination of a guarantee contract or whenever the Transporter deems same insufficient as to amount or surety, a cash deposit or a new or additional guarantee may be required for good cause upon reasonable written notice to the Shipper. The service of any Shipper who fails to comply with these requirements may be disconnected upon notice to Shipper. The Transporter shall mail the guarantor copies of all disconnect notices sent to the Shipper whose account he or she has guaranteed unless the guarantor waives such notice in writing.
9. FORCE MAJEURE
a. Except with regard to a party’s obligation to make payments due hereunder , neither party shall be liable to the other for failure to perform an obligation, to the extent such failure was caused by Force Majeure. The term “Force Majeure” as employed herein means any cause not reasonably within the control of the party claiming suspension and which could not have been prevented with the exercise of reasonable care, as further defined in this Section 9.
b. Force Majeure shall include but not be limited to the following: (i) physical events such as acts of God, landslides, lightning, earthquakes, fires, storms or storm warnings, such as hurricanes, which result in evacuation of the affected area, floods, washouts, explosions, breakage, equipment failure or accident; (ii) weather related events affecting an entire geographic region, such a low temperatures which cause freezing or failure of wells or lines of pipe or related equipment; (iii) interruption of interruptible transportation and/or storage by the Delivering Transporter(s); (iv) acts of others such as strikes. lockouts or other industrial disturbances, riots, sabotage, insurrections or wars; and (v) governmental actions such as necessity for compliance with any court order, law, statute, ordinance, or regulation promulgated by a governmental authority having jurisdiction. Shipper and Transporter shall make reasonable efforts to avoid the adverse impacts of a Force Majeure and to resolve the event or occurrence once it has occurred in order to resume performance.
c. Neither party shall be entitled to the benefit of the provisions of Force Majeure to the extent performance is affected by any or all of the following circumstances: (i) the curtailment of interruptible transportation; (ii) the party claiming excuse failed to remedy the condition and to resume the performance of such covenants or obligations with reasonable dispatch; or (iii) economic hardship.
d. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, the parties agree that the settlement of strikes, lockouts or other industrial disturbances shall be entirely within the sole discretion of the party experiencing such disturbance.
e. The party whose performance is prevented by Force Majeure must provide notice to the other party. Initial notice may be given orally; however, written notification with reasonably full particulars of the event or occurrence is required as soon as reasonably possible. Upon providing written notification of Force Majeure to the other party, the affected party will be relieved of its obligation to make or accept delivery of Gas as applicable to the extent and for the duration of Force Majeure and neither party shall be deemed to have failed in such obligations to the other during such occurrence or event.
10. BILLING AND PAYMENT
A. Information on Billing Statements
Transporter shall bill as promptly as possible following the reading of the Shipper’s meter. The Shipper’s portion of the bill shall show the present and last preceding meter readings, the date of the present reading, and number and kinds of units metered, the class of service, the amount due, the date when the bill is due, any late fees, fuel adjustment clause to the extent Shipper purchases Gas, and the amount of state and local taxes, all separately itemized. When applicable, bills shall show the net and gross amount of the bill and the date after which the gross amount must be paid. Bills rendered at rates requiring the measurement of a number of different factors, shall show all data necessary for the Shipper to check the computation of the bill. Estimated bills shall be distinctly marked as such.
B. Billing Periods
Bills shall be calculated each month and shall be payable monthly.
If the billing period is longer or shorter than the normal billing period by more than five days, the bill shall be prorated on a daily basis.
Regardless of whether a bill is based on Shipper reading, Transporter’s reading or Transporter’s estimate of consumption, Transporter shall have the right to discontinue service for non-payment with respect to delinquent bills. Upon request, the Transporter shall give the Shipper the approximate date on which he should receive his bill each month, and if a bill is not received or is lost, the Transporter shall, upon request, issue a duplicate. Failure to receive a bill shall not relieve a Shipper from payment as provided for in this Operating Statement.
C. Late Payment Charge
If the unpaid balance is in excess of $10, a late payment charge of 1.5% of the unpaid balance or $1 whichever is greater shall be added to the unpaid balance if the bill is not paid within 17 days of the current billing date. No late payment charge will be made if the unpaid balance is $10 or less.
11. ASSIGNMENT
The parties shall not assign or transfer their rights hereunder without first obtaining the non-assigning party’s written consent to such assignment or transfer, which consent will not be unreasonably withheld.
12. TAXES
Transportation fee shall include all Taxes imposed prior to or at the Delivery Point(s). The term “Taxes” includes all existing taxes, imposts, assessments or charges except ad valorem, net income, and excess profit taxes imposed or levied by any governmental authority on Transporter.
Shipper agrees to pay its proportionate part of any new taxes or increased rate of any existing tax, assessment or charge or subsequently applicable taxes, except ad valorem, net income and excess profit taxes, imposed or levied by any governmental authority as a result of any new or amended law, ordinance, enacted after December 1, 2009 which is assessed or levied against the Transporter and added to or made a part of the transportation cost of Gas transported by the Shipper hereunder. 13. APPLICABLE LAW
THIS AGREEMENT SHALL BE INTERPRETED, CONSTRUED AND GOVERNED BY THE LAWS OF THE STATE OF MINNESOTA, WITHOUT REGARD TO PRINCIPLES OF CONFLICTS OF LAWS.
14. GOVERNMENTAL REGULATIONS
This Operating Statement and the transportation arrangement hereunder are subject to all valid existing and future laws, orders, rules, regulations and proclamations of duly constituted governmental authorities having jurisdiction or control over the parties hereto or the subject matter hereof.
15. MISCELLANEOUS
a. No waiver by either party hereto of any one or more defaults by the other in the performance of any of the provisions of this Operating Statement shall operate or be construed as a waiver of any future default or defaults whether of a like kind or different nature.
b. The provisions of this Operating Statement shall not impart rights enforceable by any person, firm or organization not a party or not bound as a party, or not a successor or assignee of a party bound to this Operating Statement.
